verses.text: Praise awaits you, O God, in Zion; to you our vows will be fulfilled.
O you who hear prayer, to you all men will come.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 65
rsbNotes.text: Ps. 65 Israel’s agricultural economy depended on rainfall, which was commonly variable. This psalm thanks God for sending rain in answer to prayer.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 65:1
rsbNotes.text:
65:1 in Zion. The location chosen by God for the temple, and the place toward which praise is directed. See notes Ps. 50:2; 128:5; 129:5, and especially 2:6.

vows. When Israel brought petitions before the Lord, they frequently promised to offer sacrifices in response to answered prayer.

verses.text: When we were overwhelmed by sins, you forgave our transgressions.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 65:3
rsbNotes.text: 65:3 our transgressions. From the perspective of the sinner, there is no hope. God in His grace, however, forgives the sinner; this is a source of great joy to the psalmist.

verses.text: Blessed are those you choose and bring near to live in your courts! We are filled with the good things of your house, of your holy temple.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 65:4
rsbNotes.text:
65:4 Blessed. See Ps. 1:1.

you choose. God’s free grace is the source of blessing, and the highest blessing of all is to enjoy His fellowship (Ps. 16:11).

verses.text: You answer us with awesome deeds of righteousness, O God our Savior, the hope of all the ends of the earth and of the farthest seas,

rsbNotes.title: Ps 65:5
rsbNotes.text:
65:5 awesome deeds. God is not a distant deity who has nothing to do with His creation. He answers prayer by intervening in history and in the lives of His people.

ends of the earth. In the theologies of the surrounding lands, it was thought that there were different gods for different localities; e.g., Marduk of Babylon and Baal of Ugarit. The psalmist knows that the Lord is not simply another god among many; He is the God of the universe.

verses.text: who formed the mountains by your power, having armed yourself with strength,

rsbNotes.title: Ps 65:6
rsbNotes.text:
65:6 the mountains. A symbol of firmness and strength. God’s creation of them shows His power and greatness (Ps. 46:2, 3 and notes).

girded with might. God is clothed with power as a divine warrior who conquers the enemies of Israel (Ex. 15; Josh. 5:13–15; Judg. 5).

verses.text: who stilled the roaring of the seas, the roaring of their waves, and the turmoil of the nations.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 65:7
rsbNotes.text: 65:7 the roaring of their waves. The seas represent chaos and evil (Ps. 77:16–19 and notes), often the chaos and evil of surrounding nations who attack Israel (Dan. 7).

verses.text: Those living far away fear your wonders; where morning dawns and evening fades you call forth songs of joy.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 65:8
rsbNotes.text: 65:8 dwell at the ends of the earth. A deeper meaning of this verse was brought to light in the coming of Christ and the preaching of the gospel throughout the world.

verses.text: You care for the land and water it; you enrich it abundantly. The streams of God are filled with water to provide the people with grain, for so you have ordained it.
You drench its furrows and level its ridges; you soften it with showers and bless its crops.
You crown the year with your bounty, and your carts overflow with abundance.
The grasslands of the desert overflow; the hills are clothed with gladness.
The meadows are covered with flocks and the valleys are mantled with grain; they shout for joy and sing.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 65:9
rsbNotes.text: 65:9 water it. Compare 1 Kin. 17–19, the time of Elijah, when God cursed His rebellious people by withholding the rain.
